where_to_read: Leaves of grass are all up in my stuff

reviews.review_text: Well written. captured the Australian spirit of the times very well

This is an Australian classic that for some reason I had not read before. It is superbly written - lyrical and detailed at the same time. It records a time in Australian history that is melancholic and this oozes from the pages. But it ends on a high note, a cliffhanger really, of great promise of things to come.It feels that you are 'there' as Johnston writes about people and places.The characters are real and well portrayed and the story line is gripping. The lines between this book and the lives of George Johnston/ Jack Johnston/ and Charmian Clift are blurry, but that is irrelevant. This book is haunting.
Very well written. Graphically and accurately depicts Australian life prior, during and after the war years.

This book describes the growth, both intellectual and emotional of a working class boy, between the wars.It is as Australian in, scent as boronia in Springtime. Incredibly moving, it moves inexorably through David'srelationships with his father, his friends, his loves and his brother Jack.Cannot recommend this book highly enough.Johnson's writing soars.
i liked this book, so realistic,, could identify with the caractors,, as nice easy read.

I read this as a younger person. I knew I loved it then and I felt it again this year. This is a book filled with vulnerable, shameful, and  proud times from the written in the narrative by George Johnston.  The "Brother Jack" is the hero, and loyally presented by Johnston.This is a great read.
Well written but a bit slow.

title: My Brother Jack
word_cloud: great movie intriguing well write capture australian spirit time well australian classic reason superbly write lyrical detailed time record time australian history melancholic ooze page end high note cliffhanger really great promise thing feel write people character real well portrayed story line grip line live blurry irrelevant haunting very well write accurately depict australian life prior war year clearly write readable describe growth intellectual emotional work class boy australian scent boron move move inexorably father friend love highly write soar like realistic car actors nice easy younger person know love felt year fill vulnerable shameful proud time write narrative hero loyally present great love well write bit slow
summary:
The Miles Franklin award-winning classic. 

'The thing I am trying to get at is what made Jack different from me. Different all through our lives, I mean, and in a special sense, not just older or nobler or braver or less clever.' 

David and Jack Meredith grow up in a patriotic suburban Melbourne household during the First World War, and go on to lead lives that could not be more different. through the story of the two brothers, George Johnston created an enduring exploration of two Australian myths: that of the man who loses his soul as he gains worldly success, and that of the tough, honest Aussie battler, whose greatest ambition is to serve his country during the war. 

Acknowledged as one of the true Australian classics, My Brother Jack is a deeply satisfying, complex and moving literary masterpiece. David Meredith's story continues in the sequels Clean Straw for Nothing and A Cartload of Clay. 

'Enthralling ...entertaining ...vividly original" The Age
